awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Contributions from Thunderstorms and Electrified Shower Clouds to the Global Electric Circuit
awd_abstract_narration:
This study seeks to improve our knowledge of the role of cloud electrification in the global electric circuit (GEC).  For decades we have known that lightning-producing thunderstorms add an upward directed current, known as the Wilson current.  The GEC also consists of a downward, fair weather, current that originates from the electric potential difference between the earth's surface and the upper atmosphere.  Though these connections are well understood, no known study to date has quantified these properties using observations.  Improvements in our understanding of these processes will lead to quantitative models of the GEC, which will in turn benefit society through an improved knowledge of the role of the GEC on weather and climate.  This study provides mentorship experiences and training and supports educational diversity through the inclusion of underrepresented groups; especially Hispanic students.

This study will focus on existing cloud electrification data from ground-based radar, airborne and satellite remote sensing platforms.  This study will create a global climatology of Wilson current to describe the contribution to the GEC from thunderstorms and electrified shower clouds.  This research will also advance our understanding of the relationship between the Wilson current emanating from electrified cloud tops and their convective intensity.  Knowledge gained from this research will serve as the quantitative basis for answering larger questions of the global scale, current generators and individual life cycles of electrified cloud systems.

por.por_cntn:
The main accomplishments of this project include a) establishing the first and only electric field observatory in Arctic (at ARM NSA site at Barrow, Alaska) and collecting the data since 2017. b) completing a series of fundamental research on the relationships between the global electric circuit and global thunderstorms, interpretation of the various lightning observations and their influences, in collaboration with Drs. Michael Peterson, Wiebe Deierling, and Doug Mach. Results are published in nine journal articles and presented in multiple conferences.

This project has supported one PhD, two MS, and three undergraduate students: PhD student, Thomas Lavigne, has been supported and defended his MS thesis in June 2017 and continued PhD student on the project. Mr. Lavigne has published his first lead author research article on the global electric circuit on the Journal of Geophysical Research- Atmosphere in 2017. He has also won the first prize of student presentation on 2017 AMS annual meeting at Seattle. The he published his second paper on the relationship between thunder day and lightning density changes in 2019. He has played a key role in the field campaign at North Slope Alaska and published his third paper on the topic of electric field observations at NSA site on the Journal of Atmospheric and Solar-Terrestrial Physics in 2021. MS student Joseph Hill has joined the group in 2018 and help maintaining the electric field mill at Corpus Christi. He has completed a MS thesis in the analysis of electric field and radar properties 12 thunderstorms cases at Corpus Christi and graduated in Fall 2020. Three undergraduate students (Jacob Hale, Jose Congo, and ManhThang Nguyen) have been supported by this project in summers of 2017-2019 to work on the thunderstorms over different regions. Jacob has presented his work at AMS annual meeting at Boston in 2020. He has graduated with honors in Summer 2020.

  1. Kalb, C., W. Deierling, A. Baumgaertner, M. Peterson, C. Liu, and D. Mach (2016). Parameterizing total storm conduction currents in the community earth system model. J. Geophys. Res., 121, doi:10.1002/2016JD025376
  2. Peterson, M., W. Deierling, C. Liu, D. Mach, C. Kalb (2017). Variations in the Optical Characteristics of Lightning and the Properties of Illuminated Clouds. J. Geophys. Res. 122, 423-442.
  3. Peterson, M., W. Deierling, C. Liu, D. Mach, C. Kalb (2017). The properties of optical lightning flashes and the clouds they illuminate. J. Geophys. Res. 122, doi:10.1002/2016JD025312
  4. Lavigne, T., C. Liu, W. Deierling, and D. Mach (2017). Relationship between the global electric circuit and electrified cloud parameters at diurnal, seasonal, and interannual timescales. J. Geophys. Res. 122, 8525-8542.
  5. Peterson, M., W. Deierling, C. Liu, D. Mach, and C. Kalb (2017). A TRMM/GPM retrieval of the total mean generator current for the global electric circuit. J. Geophys. Res. 122, 10025-10049, doi:10.1002/2016JD026336.
  6. Peterson, M., W. Deierling, C. Liu, D. Mach, and C. Kalb (2018). Retrieving Global Wilson Currents from Electrified Clouds Using Satellite Passive Microwave Observations. J. Atmos. Ocean. Tech., 35, 1487-1503.
  7. Lavigne, T, and C. Liu, 2019: How does the trend in thunder-days related to the variation of lightning flash density? J. Geophys. Res., 124, 4955? 4974. doi.org/10.1029/2018JD029920.
  8. Abishek Adhikari and Chuntao Liu (2019). Geographical distribution of thundersnow events and their properties from GPM Ku-Band radar. J. Geophys. Res., 124 2031-2048.
  9. Lavigne, T., C. Liu, J. Hill, and E. Bruning, 2021: Observations from the One Year Electric Field Study-North Slope of Alaska (OYES-NSA) field campaign, and their implications for observing the distribution of global electrified cloud activity, J. Atmos. Solar. Terres. Phys., 214, 105528.
